image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Devoted friends of missing Ballarat woman Samantha Murphy begin another search for her through thick bushland.

title.children: Ballarat community members renew bushland search for Samantha Murphy

image.altText: A woman in exercise gear looks down a lonely stretch of road with trees on either side.

props.synopsis: Women in the missing Ballarat mother's hometown are either running in groups or not at all, and they're not alone in their fears — 90 per cent of women in a national running group say they joined for safety reasons.

title.children: Samantha Murphy's disappearance goes to the heart of women's fears about running alone

image.altText: Semi-automatic hunting rifle, generic image.

props.synopsis: A requirement that antique gun owners hold a firearms licence will be overturned, both major parties vow in the lead up to the Tasmanian election on March 23 — in a move slammed by anti-gun advocates as a case of Liberal and Labor politicians knowing better than police when it comes to the community's safety.

title.children: Vow to overturn police decision on antique gun regulation 'humiliating', says anti-gun advocate

image.altText: Illustration of murder victim Luke Davies, Jesse Baird and Beau Lamarre-Condon

props.synopsis: Some time between 12:01am and 5:30pm on Monday, Luke Davies and Jesse Baird were allegedly killed in Sydney. A police officer is behind bars after the week-long investigation, but more questions remain unanswered.

title.children: How police tracked down one of their own over the alleged murder of missing Sydney couple

image.altText: Collage of baby, pink flowers, scallop shell, and butterfly on dark blue background with clouds in bottom third.

props.synopsis: There are no doctors, no hospitals, not even midwives. The women who subscribe say it's "empowering" and the only way to experience true childbirth. This is the world of freebirth.

title.children: Women are choosing 'freebirth' over hospital but no-one is counting the deaths

image.altText: Dark clouds gather in the sky.

props.synopsis: Scorching end to summer expected for south-east as heavy rain falls on east and west coasts.

title.children: Return to La Niña in 2024 a strong possibility, latest modelling shows

image.altText: A family sitting alone in an empty airplane cabin

props.synopsis: The ABC has recently heard hundreds of stories from Australians with disability about their experiences with transport across the country. Advocates say systems are failing them.

title.children: Neal was trapped on a plane for hours because of his disability. Things got even worse at baggage claim

image.altText: Young man in white T-shirt in his kitchen.

props.synopsis: Trips to the GP and prescription medications are among the healthcare essentials many Australians say they can no longer afford.

title.children: Patients missing appointments, pleading for bulk-billing as cost-of-living pressures make health care a luxury

image.altText: Two women stand on a cricket ground looking at a green cap.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian Tigers women's team is hoping to secure its third straight title when it plays Queensland in the WNCL final this weekend. To boost their chances, players are drawing on the experiences and encouragement of team stalwarts.

title.children: Tasmania's women cricketers are the reigning champs — but there was a time when they didn't even have change rooms

image.altText: A fire engine and truck with men in high vis gear on a road next to the bush

props.synopsis: Police are investigating reports a car left the road and rolled, killing all four inside.

title.children: Driver and three passengers dead after car rolls in northern NSW

image.altText: Three tween in sequins pose for a photo on the platform at redfern station

props.synopsis: For thousands of unlucky Swifties who couldn’t land tickets to the Eras tour, just being near their idol was — nearly — enough.

title.children: The unofficial Eras tour: How unlucky Swifties took matters into their own hands

image.altText: A close up of a lunar lander flying close to the surface of the Moon.

props.synopsis: Experts say we may look back on the first landing of a US spacecraft on the Moon in more than 50 years as the day everything changed for space exploration.

title.children: New data suggests historic Odysseus Moon lander is lying sideways, US company says

image.altText: A man holding a gun and looking at a camera

props.synopsis: This weekend marks two years since Russian President Vladimir Putin sent his troops and tanks across the border and launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine. It's also 10 years since he illegally annexed the Crimean peninsula.

title.children: Having 'failed to make a breakthrough', Ukraine is entering a third year of war 'outgunned' and 'outmanned'

image.altText: A man stands on a boat during a musical performance, holding a flare at night

props.synopsis: Musicians Grey Filastine and Nova Ruth have lived and performed on the 70-tonne steel schooner, the Arka Kinari since 2019.

title.children: This boat was made from the same steel as Nazi U-boats. It could highlight a sustainable new future for live music

image.altText: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaking at a podium with Israeli flags in the background.

props.synopsis: The document proposes Israel would maintain security control over all land west of Jordan, including the occupied West Bank and Gaza — territories where the Palestinians hope to establish an independent state.

title.children: Netanyahu unveils plan for post-war Gaza, saying Israel would keep security control on Palestinian areas

image.altText: A military tank in camouflage print. There's a man in military uniform standing on it.

props.synopsis: Australia will be asked to consider donating its entire fleet of aging Abrams tanks to Ukraine as part of a broader package of military support that includes ammunition desperately needed in the war-torn country.

title.children: War-weary Ukraine shows renewed interest in Australia's aging Abrams tanks

image.altText: A woman wearing black clothing with purple shoulder spikes crouches on the outside of the ring mat glaring at the audience

props.synopsis: Thousands of fans, some who've travelled across the world, are eagerly anticipating the first World Wrestling Entertainment event in Perth since 2018.

title.children: Fans travel from across the country to see Aussie world champion defend her title on home soil

image.altText: A composite image of sourdough pieces on a plate and a deconstructed cheesecake.

props.synopsis: A head chef in the Sunshine Coast hinterland has made 10 dishes out of buffalo milk or meat to demonstrate the versatility of the produce.

title.children: From sourdough to sweet treats, these dishes have one key ingredient in common — buffalo milk

image.altText: American singer songwriter Taylor Swift is seen performing at Accor Stadium Sydney’s Olympic Park

props.synopsis: I've got news for you Melbourne, Sydney just brought its own special sauce to the Taylor Swift concert — and we were there, we were there, writes Sarah Gerathy.

title.children: NFL boyfriend, musical goddesses in VIP box and epic duo: Tay Tay's first Sydney show had it all

image.altText: Headshots of five men laid over a cloudy background beneath type saying Missing Persons

props.synopsis: Four bodies, a remote cabin, and a man starved to death next to a locker stacked with food — almost half a century later, investigators remain searching for answers.

title.children: 'They didn't come home': Five men disappeared in 1978. What happened to them has never been explained

image.altText: Ben Yole holds bridle of a horse.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian harness racing trainer at the centre of a report that made findings of race fixing, team driving and animal welfare breaches wins an appeal to overturn his "warning off" from Australian racetracks.

title.children: Banned Tasmanian harness racing trainer Ben Yole wins appeal against warning off from racetracks

image.altText: A silhouette of a pregnant woman outside.

props.synopsis: Reporters Charlotte King and Andy Burns detail the work that went into their investigation into freebirth in Australia.

title.children: Balancing a mother's right to privacy and the public's right to know in a period of intense trauma

image.altText: An ariel view of several race cars at the first corner of a race, in front of fans.

props.synopsis: Record crowds have descended on Bathurst for the 500. Drivers are hoping the race becomes a permanent fixture on the calendar as part of plans to expand racing at Mount Panorama-Wahluu.

title.children: Bathurst 500 returns to Mount Panorama-Wahluu, but will it be back in 2025?

image.altText: Long-haired man decked in a striped blazer and chain necklaces smiling to the camera

props.synopsis: A US judge dismisses the case against Steven Tyler, frontman of the American rock band Aerosmith, saying the plaintiff "waited too long to sue".

title.children: Aerosmith's Steven Tyler has 1975 sexual assault allegation dismissed

image.altText: a young man wearing a blue collared shirt outside court

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory coroner has heard former constable Zachary Rolfe texted another person about "smashing" a remote community, with a colleague saying he likely meant police had "achieved their goal" and "upheld the law".

title.children: 'Absolutely ridiculous': NT Police sergeant questioned over Zachary Rolfe texts, in police shooting inquest

image.altText: Forest with fire glow in background during bushfire.

props.synopsis: A 13-year-old and 67-year-old are found lighting fires in separate incidents in Tasmania's south during a total fire ban, with police investigating the deliberately-lit fires which began on Tuesday and are still burning in the state's Central Highlands.

title.children: Two caught lighting fires during Tasmania's total fire ban, as police still hunt firebugs who sparked Central Highlands blazes

image.altText: A composite image showing influencer Tully Smyth.

props.synopsis: Testimonial promotion of regulated health services is illegal under Australia's advertising laws, but paid partnerships with influencers about egg freezing continue to appear on social media feeds, with the health regulator saying it is a "complex" legal area.

title.children: Fertility services are paying social media influencers to promote egg freezing — but is that legal?

image.altText: Four people in black suits stand around a recently dug grave which is yet to be filled in with dirt

props.synopsis: Each year, hundreds of people who "fall through the cracks" are buried in country Victoria by volunteers who never knew them.

title.children: Without a loved one to bury them, the dead are laid to rest at this volunteer-run cemetery

image.altText: A woman shines a torch into the wiring of an aircraft as she examines the plane for maintenance.

props.synopsis: As industries across Australia try to solve staff and trainee shortages, an aviation company has started targeting half the nation's population.

title.children: Aviation company says you don't have to look to the skies for solution to nation's trades shortage

image.altText: A man dressed in a suit and a woman dressed in a white suit stand on a balcony next to a scenic view of the ocean.

props.synopsis: When Italy became a republic, its former monarchs were forced into exile. In the decades since, two branches of the family have been locked in a squabble over who is the rightful ruler to Italy's non-existent throne.

title.children: With the son of Italy's last king dead, a decades-long battle over a defunct crown is laid bare

image.altText: Composit pygmy possum and reef

props.synopsis: As Queensland environmentalists continue to fight looming coal mine approvals, Australia's Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek is relying on arguments that have come under increasing scrutiny in climate litigation.

title.children: Does the 'drug dealer defence' still hold up in climate law cases?

image.altText: Dungeon master Emma Powell playing D&D

props.synopsis: Once seen as the domain of teenage boys in their parents' basements, Dungeons and Dragons is broadening its player base and enjoying a resurgence in popularity.

title.children: Dungeons and Dragons' latest wave of adventurers roll with the punches
